title: The special code in editor has no Authority control and can lead to Information Disclosure

profile.name: Phabricator
profile.about: Phabricator is a collection of open source web applications that help software companies build better software.

vulnerability_information:
Here is your keyword:mongoose

Details:
- Summary:

Uploaded file will be showed as a special code `{Fxxx}` in Phabricator editor,but it has no Authority control.

- Reproduce steps:

1.Open two different browsers (to simulate two different users)
2.browser A:login as user "toma"
3.browser B:login a user "test4"
4.user "toma" create a Maniphest task with visibility "toma" only,and upload a file "toma.html" to description,its code is`{F18}`
5.user "test4" open anyone editor and write:
```
{F1}{F2}{F3}{F4}{F4}{F5}{F6}{F7}{F8}{F9}{F10}{F11}{F12}{F13}{F14}{F15}{F16}{F17}{F18}{F19}{F20}
```
then post it,then you will find user "test4" has got the file of user "toma" with visibility "toma".
vulnerability_information_html:
Here is your keyword:mongoose

Details:

  • Summary:

Uploaded file will be showed as a special code {Fxxx} in Phabricator editor,but it has no Authority control.

  • Reproduce steps:

1.Open two different browsers (to simulate two different users)
2.browser A:login as user "toma"
3.browser B:login a user "test4"
4.user "toma" create a Maniphest task with visibility "toma" only,and upload a file "toma.html" to description,its code is{F18}
5.user "test4" open anyone editor and write:

{F1}{F2}{F3}{F4}{F4}{F5}{F6}{F7}{F8}{F9}{F10}{F11}{F12}{F13}{F14}{F15}{F16}{F17}{F18}{F19}{F20}

then post it,then you will find user "test4" has got the file of user "toma" with visibility "toma".

activities.message:
I can't reproduce this. Here's what I did:

1. Opened two browsers.
2. Logged in as "hector" in browser A.
3. Logged in as "dog" in browser B.
4. In browser A, as "hector", created a task visible by and editable by "hector" only, then uploaded a file and posted it in a comment. See screenshots (1) and (2). The file ID was `{F28315}`. I also edited the description to include this file. See screenshot (3).
5. In browser B, as "dog", posted `{F28315}` in a comment. See screenshots (4) and (5).

The file content was not revealed to user "dog" in browser B.

What can I do differently to reproduce this issue?

activities.message:
OK,I will re-describe once more clearly.

Reproduce steps:
1.Open two different browsers (to simulate two different users)
2.browser A:login as user "tomb"
3.browser B:login a user "rrr"
4.user "tomb" create a Maniphest task with visibility "All people" at first,and upload a file "toma.html" to description,its code is`{F15}` .see screenshot(1)
5.Then go to browser B(rrr),edit profile and write `{F15}`,post it.see screenshot(2)
6.Then go to browser A(tomb).edit that Maniphest task with visibility "tomb" only
7.Then go to browser B(rrr).refresh profile page,you can find that file `{F15}` is still here. see screenshot(3)

activities.message:
In screenshot (2), you are adding the file to a user profile. Anyone can see user profiles, so this means anyone can now see the file.

You can think of this a bit like sending an email. In screenshot (2), it's like you're sending an email to a mailing list with every user on it, and attaching the file to that email. Now everyone can see the file because you've sent it to a public list as an email attachment.

Things work the same way if you attach a file to a task which is visible to "All Users" or "Public". It's like sending an email with the file as an attachment to a public list.

All of the behavior described here appears to be expected behavior, and nothing violates policies.
activities.markdown_message:
In screenshot (2), you are adding the file to a user profile. Anyone can see user profiles, so this means anyone can now see the file.

You can think of this a bit like sending an email. In screenshot (2), it's like you're sending an email to a mailing list with every user on it, and attaching the file to that email. Now everyone can see the file because you've sent it to a public list as an email attachment.

Things work the same way if you attach a file to a task which is visible to "All Users" or "Public". It's like sending an email with the file as an attachment to a public list.

All of the behavior described here appears to be expected behavior, and nothing violates policies.

activities.message:
No,No,please wait a moment.

I use `edit profile` just want to use a editor,this is a random selection.So your first sentence is not true.

And then I don't think this like sending an email with an attachment.This just a problem for`can see` or `can not see`.

`All public` means I want all people to see this task including the files.

`visibility for tomb only` means I don't want anyone to see it including files.

So this is probably a design flaw,when you change the task permissions, there is no change to the file permissions.

Thanks!

activities.message:
If you believe there is a real issue here, please give me a set of reproduction instructions which allow user "B" to see the content of a file they should not be able to see, *without* user "A" attaching that file to any object (task, user, etc) which user "B" can see.

That is, this is an expected behavior:

  - User "A" uploads a file, attaching it to something user "B" can see (a task, user, revision, wiki page, chatroom, etc).
  - User "B" can now see the file.

When user "A" attaches a file to a public object, they are sharing it with anyone who can see that object.

This is also an expected behavior:

  - User "A" uploads a file, attaching it to something user "B" can not see (like a private task).
  - User "B" can _not_ see the file.

My screenshots above show that this behavior appears to be working correctly.

You can see which objects a file is attached to by navigating to the `/Fxxxx` page (for example, `https://phabricator.local.com/F123` and clicking the "Attached" tab. If that tab lists any object (like a task) which user "B" can see, it is expected that user "B" will be able to see the file.

I haven't been able to follow any set of steps to violate either of these expected behaviors. As far as I can tell, Phabricator is working as designed and policies are not being violated.

activities.message:
Yes,I agree with you opinions.

```
That is, this is an expected behavior:

  - User "A" uploads a file, attaching it to something user "B" can see (a task, user, revision, wiki page, chatroom, etc).
  - User "B" can now see the file.

When user "A" attaches a file to a public object, they are sharing it with anyone who can see that object.

This is also an expected behavior:

  - User "A" uploads a file, attaching it to something user "B" can not see (like a private task).
  - User "B" can _not_ see the file.

```

This is definitely working fine.Phabricator is working as designed and policies are not being violated.

=================

And the opinion which I want to express is:

In the two status(`private` and `public`) transition time, the program forgot to change the file permissions.

I think this is not the original design of the system.

=================

And the opinion which I want to express is:

activities.message:
Comment 2 is one of the methods of reproduction.

And you can try another reproduction:

1.If user "A" create a `maniphest private task` and upload a file `{F17}` (for example),user "B" also create a task and write `{F17}`,user "B" will `got nothing with preview`,still a string of code `{F17}` 

2.If user "A" create a `maniphest public task` and upload a file `{F17}` (for example),user "B" also create a task and write `{F17}`,user "B" will `got this file with preview` ,not still a string of code `{F17}` 

3.If user "A" create a `maniphest public task` and upload a file `{F17}` (for example),user "B" also create a task and write `{F17}`,user "B" will `got this file at first with preview`,then user "A" change task to `private`,then user "B" will `got nothing  with preview again`

4.If user "A" create a `maniphest public task` and upload a file `{F17}` (for example),user "B" also create a task and write `{F17}`,user "B" will `got this file at first with preview` and then `user "B" post it`,then user "A" change task to `private`,`the file still exists in user "B" 's task`
activities.markdown_message:
Comment 2 is one of the methods of reproduction.

And you can try another reproduction:

1.If user "A" create a maniphest private task and upload a file {F17} (for example),user "B" also create a task and write {F17},user "B" will got nothing with preview,still a string of code {F17}

2.If user "A" create a maniphest public task and upload a file {F17} (for example),user "B" also create a task and write {F17},user "B" will got this file with preview ,not still a string of code {F17}

3.If user "A" create a maniphest public task and upload a file {F17} (for example),user "B" also create a task and write {F17},user "B" will got this file at first with preview,then user "A" change task to private,then user "B" will got nothing with preview again

4.If user "A" create a maniphest public task and upload a file {F17} (for example),user "B" also create a task and write {F17},user "B" will got this file at first with preview and then user "B" post it,then user "A" change task to private,the file still exists in user "B" 's task

activities.message:
That's expected. Here's a similar workflow:

- User "A" creates a public task and uploads the file.
- User "B" can see the file now, so they save the file to their desktop, then print out a copy and hang it on their wall, then email it to themselves, then give it to a friend.
- User "A" later makes the task private.
- User "B" still has all their copies. User "A" should reasonably expect that as soon as he has made the file public, other users can download copies, share them, and access them later.

This is not a bug in Phabricator and not a security issue.
activities.markdown_message:

  • User "A" creates a public task and uploads the file.
  • User "B" can see the file now, so they save the file to their desktop, then print out a copy and hang it on their wall, then email it to themselves, then give it to a friend.
  • User "A" later makes the task private.
  • User "B" still has all their copies. User "A" should reasonably expect that as soon as he has made the file public, other users can download copies, share them, and access them later.

This is not a bug in Phabricator and not a security issue.

activities.message:
If you re-edit user "B" task,you will realize that it is still a code `{F17}` in editor(not an attachment),and the system did not realize it was a private file at this time, and still parsed it.
I do not always think this is  similar to send email with attachments；
The system still parses code `{F17}` as a public file.

This is not a bug.
